div1.p: Consulate General of the United States Monrovia Dec, 2 1886
The celebration of the 1st of Dec, '86.
Consulate General of the United States Monrovia Dec. 2, 1886.
Hon. T. F. Bayard Secy of State Washington D.C.

Sir: I have the honor respectfully to inform you that the 1st of Dec, 1886 was celebrated by the authorities and citizens of Liberia as a public holiday on account of the achievement obtained by the early settlers of this city (Monrovia the capital) over the day-tribes once the most powerful tribe on the West Coast of

of Africa. The day was pleasantly spent. The President of the Republic of Liberia had public reception in the capital at the exactive mansion. I had the honor to be present and took occasion to pay tribute of respect to the memory of the early heroes of those days who fought manfully to gain this Republic. His excellency the President H. R. W. Johnson proposed the health of the President of the United States which was received cheerfully. In recognition of which I

I spoke of the President Grover Clevland; his zeal, his earnestness in the performance of his weighty responsibilities and of the strength and grandeur of the government of the United States which will ever live as ages roll on into eternity. I pray the government of the United States may even live to take active part in the concerns generally in my race in this dark and benighted land.
I remain Sir Your obedient servant.
Samuel S. Sevier Acting Consul General
